snippet: Experts say a 2005 deposition in which Bill Cosby admits to philandering could be used against him, but they also point out that the burden of proof is high.
abstract: Legal experts say public disclosure of deposition Bill Cosby provided in 2005 sexual assault suit could be used against him in two current defamation cases; lawyers caution that burden of proof is high, and that disclosure might not be particularly helpful in bringing new lawsuits against Cosby for incidents alleged to have occurred long ago.

byline.original: By GRAHAM BOWLEY and SYDNEY EMBER

lead_paragraph: Experts say a 2005 deposition in which Bill Cosby admits to philandering could be used against him, but they also point out that the burden of proof is high.

headline.main: Uncertainty on Whether Cosby Revelations Could Hurt Him in Court
headline.print_headline: Uncertainty as to Whether Cosby’s Words Could Hurt Him in Court
